body:
I have to say I don't why CentOS has a different directory structure from Ubuntu.

But this should be the reason that R can't find the lib.

I am sorry but I could not see how to use it for my case. To be more precise here is my example .lst file lines which includes different number on labels for different instances;

```
10  156.0   195.0   184.0   134.0   56af33fd93427e0f448335e60.jpg
11  156.0   195.0   177.0   8.0 56af33cc93427e0f4483353c0.jpg
12  156.0   124.0   343.0   56af33d593427e0f448335470.jpg
13  156.0   124.0   128.0   50.0    56af33cd93427e0f4483353d0.jpg
14  156.0   26.0    185.0   349.0   244.0   56af33fd93427e0f448335e80.jpg
15  156.0   26.0    185.0   349.0   244.0   56af33fd93427e0f448335e81.jpg
```

So for instance I like to use 156.0 195.0 184.0 134.0 as correct labels for the first instance not only one label but all of these. Still bucketing is a way?

I think to use PrefetchingIter which includes different iterators with different label_width values. Is is viable ?
Maybe it's because of the `r_arch` option that is used when R is built on that platform. I will talk to the guy who is in charge of that. Thanks so far for your kind help!

Really little experience on CentOS.

## 

Qiang Kou
qkou@umail.iu.edu
School of Informatics and Computing, Indiana University
So I assume the new (7th) release doesn't solve the issue yet? How is it with you @JohanManders? I haven't had time to work on my desktop to test it yet.

OK. Re: Spark with mxnet. My takeaway is your preferred approach is to use a Parameter Server vs the synchronized training (the SparkNet approach). 

There might be two solutions here:
    (a)  Write your own Spark interface
    (b)   Collaborate with SparkNet to enhance their platform to support a  Parameter Server 

Have you also considered the (b) approach?  If so why was it not chosen?  

Thanks!
Re: the C API Presets: they  would be helpful yes! thanks.  I am new to this and would not be able to answer if C++ were required though I would venture a guess that no.

@javadba Since SparkNet, according to its published paper, is a synchronized approach, it seems that ps cannot take advantage of any exist interface in SparkNet. But I'm still open to any possible choice. Also correct me if I'm wrong.

Hi Yizhi,   thanks for the response. I am new to both projects and am
learning myself what are their characteristics. My team is looking for a
distributed gpu support for deep learning - and both mxnet and SparkNet
seem to have pieces of the answer that may be useful.  We will look more
into/understand better  the Parameter Server vs Synchronous approaches to
be more helpful in these disucssions.
Thanks.

2016-02-17 8:45 GMT-08:00 Yizhi Liu notifications@github.com:

> @javadba https://github.com/javadba Since SparkNet, according to its
> published paper, is a synchronized approach, it seems that ps cannot take
> advantage of any exist interface in SparkNet. But I'm still open to any
> possible approach. Also correct me if I'm wrong.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/842#issuecomment-185292076.
@Quares I have tried the latest build, Windows binary build 20160216, and I still have the problem.

I think we are open for the options in terms of integrations. MXNet already support YARN and I think spark integration is one the plan.

One key difference between the project you mentioned here is. While caffe style model follows a config and run strategy, which is fine for pre-defined CNN. MXNet focuses on maximum customization via hybrid declarative and imperative API.

Here are some examples I believe which is easier in mxnet:
- Use scala to define customized optimization algorithm that runs on GPU
- Fully take advantage of the scala NDArray API, so you can do other strange stuffs besides data parallel training of a model.

This being said, the goal of mxnet is being portable, this should include being able to easily ported to other projects, as well as being able to port to major platforms. We have done this for MPI, YARN and I suppose spark or even flink is another natural option

Thanks for the contribution! This can be very helpful for people working on MCMC.
Can you also make an notebook on bayesian dark knowledge? 

Let us also think about folder name, maybe MCMC or bayesian-method could be a better name. We could possibly add other optimizers like SGHMC and SGNHT
Please do a rebase to merge the commits into one as in http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/contribute.html#how-to-combine-multiple-commits-into-one
@antinucleon can you review this?

Thanks Tianqui for that insight.  MxNet sounds like a great project!   We
are  interested in the dynamic / runtime / flexible algorithmic declaration
approach that you mention.  So we will be interested in these developments
going forward.

I just found that I have the same problem, tried both mnist and cifar10 examples. I am using GTX980 and Windows 10.

I tried different builds and found that all snapshots after build20151228 do not work, also spotted that the file size has been reduced very much since build 20151228 --- are there changes in compilation config?

I tried link to the provided CUDA/CuDNN DLL files and also my own DLLs (same version) via different PATH, did not work either. 

Perhaps it maybe a compiler / OS level issue.

@Rafel-Mou only need change in deconvolution-inl.h, not convolution.
because someone may changes the code in the newest mxnet, you may use my branch: https://github.com/tornadomeet/mxnet/tree/seg
done

Sorry about that... I just re-uploaded the packages. It is ok now.

@shenxiul , thanks for you reply!!! Your are rounding `pred` here, thus you are assuming that pred is a vector of float numbers instead of 0s and 1s
@paipai880429 Yes, it is probability rather than predicting label, oh I didn't realize that you don't round it... Sorry I should state it earlier.
These kind of questions best got to the (new and shiny) forum at forum.dmlc.ml
@shenxiul Really thank you for your quick response! And, happy new year.

@thyu Could you try the C++ program in the test branch of https://github.com/hjk41/MxNet.cpp.git
I have recreated the problem with a Windows 10 machine in Python, but the C++ program runs just fine
Thank you
The best way is to push a write operation to the engine, write to the variable of the array, with the lambda function being delete

see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/include/mxnet/ndarray.h#L330
on how ndarray delete its memory, the lambda function will only be executed after the dependency is fullfilled
Fine, I'll work on a notebook for BDK. For the folder name, I think bayesian-method would be better and we can add more Bayesian modeling examples to this folder in the future.

@tqchen The problem is not with the NDArrays (yet), but with the `std::vectors` that store the pointers and tags to the NDArrays. More or less what I want is to schedule a lambda once the NDArrays have been written to.
@paipai880429 Happy new year, shall we close this issue?
Totally agreed with @tqchen . I hope scala package can make MXNet more portable to other JVM platforms.
Conversation continued in http://forum.dmlc.ml/t/how-to-use-triplet-loss-in-mxnet/33

No package 'opencv' found
/bin/sh: 1: g++-4.8: not found
make: **\* [build/src/resource.o] Error 127
@piiswrong I have merge in master:)

Which platform are you working on?
Could you try to locate the layer that is causing this?

My platform:
Red Hat 4.4.7-4.
Linux version 2.6.32-431.el6.x86_64.

The only difference in the code is kCPU or kGPU.

I wondered it was because of the data copy between CPU and GPU,  so I add ndarray_wait_all() everywhere, but it seems not to be the answer.
Try running only the first layer, then the first two. See if you can locate the layer that cause mismatching results.

Seems CPU are giving a wrong results?
The output of bn_conv1_output given by CPU are all -6.85604e+09.
While the GPU results are a lot more resonable.
(The output of conv_conv1_output of GPU and CPU are identical)

What will this mean?

The first few layers of the model:

```
[16:48:26] feature_extract.cpp:26: data
[16:48:26] feature_extract.cpp:26: conv_conv1_weight
[16:48:26] feature_extract.cpp:26: conv_conv1_bias
[16:48:26] feature_extract.cpp:26: conv_conv1_output
[16:48:26] feature_extract.cpp:26: bn_conv1_gamma
[16:48:26] feature_extract.cpp:26: bn_conv1_beta                                                                                                             
[16:48:26] feature_extract.cpp:26: bn_conv1_output
```

So I find the cause.
I didn't load the aux parameters from the Model.

close the issue.

I was wondering where I could find the GRU examples?
@tqchen Are there plans to allow the R package to support sparse input too?

So here is the problem, because call into julia is async (aha), the PushSync on julia may not necessarily  happen before the last PushSync which notifies the completion and finishes all the jobs.  

This is a really tricky thing and I guess the only solution maybe offer another callback to Julia to enable it notify its completion in the async call.

@hjk41 
Seems fine?

``` bash
$ ./MxnetTestApp.exe
0 1 2 3 4 5
```

Yes. So it seems to be something in Python/R binding or how they use the
library.

Closing this now. Feel free to reopen.
I had similar issue with Windows x64. Rebuilt libmxnet.dll from scratch and it started working OK.
Backward doesn't seem correct. Could you add a test case?

It's in the backend at src/operators/regression_output-inl.h.

@tqchen How about we put some comment in symbol.py to explain where/how things are registered.
@jimxinbo, thank you for your sharing~!

I am new to mxnet. I am thinking to work on this problem. I have thought of three ways to deal with problem 1. one is omitting the rows with missing data 2. using mean for prediction 3. using EM algorithm before processing . I want to know how missing data is handled in other packages. Any guidance on how to proceed further?
`libippicv` is part of opencv. Please make sure you installed opencv properly.

Personally it is users' responsibility to decide how to handle missing data.

I think we can provide some functions, but we can't do that automatically.
so what kind of functions might be helpful ?
yes forward is less expensive than backward.
so even "is_train=False"? So what is the point of setting this flag? @piiswrong
Thank you. I have resolved!

Usually in these situations, you are not supposed to use something like [matrix completion ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_completion) algo? What else can be done?

It can't be fixed as easily that in XGboost as we can't easily tell the #nnet NA is a special value. How to compute a partial derivative on it?
You're right, I should have checked the Backward implementation. This variant should be correct now, I also changed the spelling of DropoutAllchannels to DropoutAllChannels
Some layer's behavior is different depending on this flag.
An exception will be thrown. Don't do that.
Update then I will merge in

And also, Adam takes 2g memory more than ccsgd. In my case, ccsgd only takes 2.5g, but Adam takes 4.5, sometimes, near 5g. Is there any way that this can be optimised? Or is it supposed to be like this?
@pommedeterresautee I agree with you. We can give a warning, even an error, when the data set has NA. It is users who need to decide how to handle missing values.

Yeah probably just some warnings since new users might not be sure how to deal with NAs in the evaluation metrics. @thirdwing 

I was mistakenly thinking this can be handled like in xgboost. @pommedeterresautee thanks for correcting me.
ccsgd saves memory because it's implemented in C++ and doesn't allocate any temp memory. You can implement adam in cpp to get similar performance.

deconvolution with 2x upsampling can be done like this:

```
scale = 2
pred1 = mx.symbol.Deconvolution(data=pred1, kernel=(2*scale, 2*scale), stride=(scale, scale), pad=(scale/2, scale/2), num_filter=33, no_bias=True, workspace=workspace, name=prefix+'deconv_pred1')
```
Great, thanks

Hi, @mateuszr 

Actually I spent some time on autoencoder in R https://github.com/thirdwing/mxnet/blob/autoencoder/example/autoencoder/autoencoder.R

But I don't have enough time to finish it.

Besides, I am also thinking about a question: does R user prefer the high-level API, such as in h2o, or examples building networks step by step?

Hello! 
That looks very good! Btw. I'm getting "Error: not compatible with requested type" when testing it with MNIST dataset. Do you have some running example of invocation for the AE_setup()?

Regarding the API question: I can speak only for myself, but I suppose that some clean high-level API (but with enough parameters for some hyperparameter optimisation) probably solves most use cases and provides a very good starting point for experimentation. For other custom autoencoders, people would probably construct their own networks...
Best,

Thanks for creating the note!! Since this note can be used in a standalone way, and we want to keep images from the main repo to reduce the size. 

Let us consider first create a Link to your repo from  https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/README.md first :)

@thyu @jonathanponce @JohanManders @Quares @piiswrong 
Could you help me check with the latest binary build here? [https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/releases/tag/20160223](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/releases/tag/20160223)
I think it is the problem with CUDA library. Windows Server 2012 and Windows 10/8 uses different CUDA binaries so I assume there is some difference between the libraries we link. The libmxnet.dll compiled on Windows 2012 does not work on Windows 10/8, and vice versa. 

The latest binary was compiled on Windows 10 and it works well on my machine. But I don't have another Windows 10/8/7 machine to test on. So could you help me validate this?
@hjk41 Your latest builds seems to work perfectly! Thanks man, this helps me a lot! The mnist example now outputs a train accuracy of 0.999 and validation accuracy of 0.991.
@JohanManders Great! I will use Windows 10 in the future for building the binary distribution.
I would like to tackle this issue if it is open.
Great news! I will test it in the evening and will let you know.

Thanks @piiswrong ,
I have another question regarding to the prediction. 
My prediction is a segmented image (256x256) which has 2 classes (membrane at value 0 and non-membrane at value 255). In this case, how to write a softmax layer? (as the network can output the right image)

![alt text](http://brainiac2.mit.edu/isbi_challenge/sites/default/files/Challenge-ISBI-2012-Animation-Input-Labels.gif)

I appreciate your helps a lot. 

Sincerely,
CSVIter currently do not support shuffle, mainly because it does not assume things can be loaded into memory
I think this is related to #842
@antinucleon will be leading discussion on this issue
@rohit12 Have opened a detailed thread to discuss this in #1524

Here linked is a RNN model learning 8-digit binary addition, which is implemented in Rcpp. Though not high-level implementation, it might be helpful for some others who want to participate in this GSOC project, as Cpp/Rcpp is much involved.

See: https://gist.github.com/Puriney/072a37ea8a181f0b6168

I have great interest in GSOC. If possible, could your mentors list easy->medium->hard tests?
Consider create a adapter that combines data from two data iter into one?
This is not yet changed in spec. For temp solution, what we do is always explicitly copy to cpu before serialization
closing for now
@hjk41 The latest build works!!! Thanks!    You rock!!!!

Is it possible to raise a Warning if shuffle is set to True, then?

> assume things can be loaded into memory

> â€”

> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1523#issuecomment-187795589.

This is rooted into whether we are able to report unknown parameters in IOIter.

It is a bit hard in current case, mainly because the real iterator is nested combination of several iterators, with each take part of the parameters. An error will be raised for other cases, such as operators when wrong parameter is presented.
Maybe you can try an easy/medium/hard issue.

I am happy that it works, but I also see a big speed difference between Windows and Ubuntu. For Windows I downloaded the latest pre-built package 20160223. For Ubuntu I just downloaded the latest version and build it.

I did two tests on my dual-boot i7 system with a GTX 670:

train_mnist.py

```
Windows 7 | Build 20160223                        : ~  6750 samples / sec
Ubuntu    | Downloaded en build a few minutes ago : ~ 20000 samples / sec
```

Training on other data

```
Windows 7 | Build 20160223                        : ~ 49 sec / epoch
Ubuntu    | Downloaded en build a few minutes ago : ~ 31 sec / epoch
```

TensorFlow has sparse tensors and indexedslices tensors, which are sparse in first dimension but dense in other dimensions.

I think I would be easier to support the later first and it satisfies most use cases.
Sgd with momentum can also benefit from sparse update by recording iteration count of the last update.
One other feature we are missing is stride and general slicing.
It does normalize the loss. So use a larger learning rate
